10876Journal of Cluster ScienceIncluding Nanoclusters and NanoparticlesJ Clust Sci1040-72781572-8862Springer USBostons10876-011-0428-942810.1007/s10876-011-0428-9Original PaperNew BPTH-Bridged Chained Cd(II) Coordination Polymer Based on Cd2O2 Clusters: Synthesis and Crystal Structure of [Cd(BPTH)(phen)]·3.75H2O (BPTH = biphthalhydrazidate; phen = phenanthroline)JinJuan1JiaMing-Jun2ZhaoJin-Jing1YuJie-Hui1dXuJi-Qing1egrid.64924.3d0000000417605735College of Chemistry and State Key Laboratory of Inorganic Synthesis and Preparative ChemistryJilin University130023ChangchunJilinPeople’s Republic of Chinagrid.64924.3d0000000417605735Key Laboratory of Surface and Interface Chemistry of Jilin Province, College of ChemistryJilin UniversityQianjin Road 2699130012ChangchunJilinPeople’s Republic of Chinajiehuiyu@yahoo.com.cnxjq@mail.jlu.edu.cn71220116201223228729528112011241020117122011© Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 20112011Abstract

Based on the hydrothermal in situ acylation reaction of 4,4′-biphthalic acid (bpha) with N2H4·H2O, a new acylhydrazidate-bridged 1-D chained Cd2+ coordination polymer [Cd(BPTH)(phen)]·3.75H2O (BPTH = 4,4′-biphthalhydrazidate, phen = phenanthroline) was synthesized, and characterized by elemental analysis, infrared spectroscopy, powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), thermogravimetric analysis and single-crystal XRD. With ancillary phen molecules, the BPTH molecules link the Cd2+ centers into a 1-D staircase chain structure of compound 1 based on the Cd2O2 clusters.

Graphical Abstract

Based on the hydrothermal in situ acylation reaction of 4,4′-biphthalic acid (bpha) with N2H4·H2O, a new acylhydrazidate-bridged 1-D chained Cd2+ coordination polymer [Cd(BPTH)(phen)]·3.75H2O (BPTH = 4,4′-biphthalhydrazidate, phen = phenanthroline) was synthesized. With ancillary phen molecules, the BPTH molecules link the Cd2+ centers into a 1-D staircase chain structure of compound 1 based on the Cd2O2 clusters.

The ligand in situ synthesis provides a new approach towards the construction of the novel coordination polymer materials with interesting structures and useful properties [1–3]. At recent, one of the investigations for our group is focused on the structural characterization of the acylhydrazidate-bridged coordination polymers. Herein the acylhydrazidate ligands originated from the hydrothermal in situ acylation reactions between organic polycarboxylic acids and N2H4·H2O. So far, the employed polycarboxylic acids in our lab include phthalic acid, pyridine-2,3-dicarboxylic acid, pyridine-3,4-dicarboxylic acid, 6-methylpyridine-2,3-dicarboxylic acid, 5-ethylpyridine-2,3-dicarboxylic acid, benzene-1,2,4-tricarboxylic acid, 4,5-dichlorophthalic acid and 4,4′-oxydiphthalic acid. The obtained typical acylhydrazidate-bridged coordination polymers include the 0-D [Pb2(ODPTH)2(phen)2(H2O)2] [4], 1-D [Pb(2,3-PDH)2] [5], [Mn(MPDH)2] [6], [Pb2(EPDH)4(H2O)] [7], [Pb2(DCPTH)4(phen)2] [8], 2-D [Cu(PTH)] [5], [Pb4(OH)2(H2O)3(CPTH)3]·2H2O [9] as well as the 3-D [Pb(3,4-PDH)2] [5] (ODPTH = 4,4′-oxydiphthalhydrazidate; 2,3-PDH = pyridine-2,3-dicarboxylhydrazidate; MPDH = 6-methylpyridine-2,3-dicarboxylhydrazidate; EPDH = 5-ethylpyridine-2,3-dicarboxylhydrazidate; DCPTH = dicholophthalhydrazidate; 3,4-PDH = pyridine-3,4-dicarboxyhydrazidate; PTH = phthalhydrazidate; CPTH = 4-carboxylphthalhydrazidate; phen = phenanthroline). In these compounds, the metal ions and the O atoms form the various aggregations. Moreover, most of them show the interesting photoluminescence properties due to the existence of multi-types of charge transfer paths in the compounds. In this article, 4,4′-biphthalic acid (bpha) was selected as the acid precursor, and a new 4,4′-biphthalhydrazidate-bridged 1-D chained coordination polymer [Cd(BPTH)(phen)] (BPTH = 4,4′-biphthalhydrazidate) 1 was luckily obtained.

Experimental

All chemicals are of reagent grade quality, obtained from commercial sources without further purification. Elemental analysis (C, H and N) was performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400LS II elemental analyzer. Infrared (IR) spectrum was recorded on a Perkin Elmer Spectrum 1 spectrophotometer in 4,000–400 cm−1 region using a powdered sample on a KBr plate. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were collected on a Rigaku/max-2550 diffractometer with Cu–Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). Thermogravimetric (TG) behavior was investigated on a Perkin-Elmer TGA-7 instrument with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 in air.

[Cd(BPTH)(phen)]·3.75H<sub>2</sub>O <bold>1</bold>

To a 15 mL aqueous solution, bpha (147 mg, 0.5 mmol) and N2H4·H2O (0.1 mL) were added, and the mixture was stirred for 30 min. Cd(CH3COO)2·3H2O (133 mg, 0.5 mmol) and phen·H2O (99 mg, 0.5 mmol) were further added, and the mixture continued to be stirred for 3 h. Then the resulting solution (pH 5 adjusted by dilute CH3COOH) was sealed in a 30-mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessels and heated in an oven at 170 °C for 4 days. Upon cooling automatically to the room temperature, yellow block crystals of 1 were obtained by filtration, washed with distilled water and dried in air at the ambient temperature. Yield: ca. 20% based on Cd(II). Anal. Calcd. C28H23.5N6O7.75Cd 1: C 49.43, H 3.48, N 12.35%. Found: C 48.14, H 3.99, N 12.10%. IR (cm−1): 1651 s, 1558 s, 1490 s, 1440 m, 1380 m, 1342 m, 1265 w, 1207 m, 1070 m, 845 s, 793 s, 722 s, 678 w.

Data were collected with Mo–Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) on a Siemens SMART CCD diffractometer. With SHELXTL program, compound 1 was solved using direct methods, and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques. The non-hydrogen atoms were assigned anisotropic displacement parameters in the refinement, and the hydrogen atoms were treated using a riding model. The structure was then refined on F2 using SHELXL-97. CCDC number is 833993 for 1. The crystallographic data are summarized in Table 1. The selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table 2.

Results and Discussion

In the synthesis of compound 1, the aim that bpha and N2H4·H2O were first mixed and stirred for 30 min is to induce the occurrence of the acylation reaction, avoiding producing the carboxylate-bridged coordination polymer. Scheme 1 gives the forming process of the BPTH molecule. One molar bpha interacts with two molar N2H4·H2O, losing six molar water molecules to produce the acylhydrazide molecule.

Based on the acylation reaction mechanism (see Scheme 1), the biphthalhydrazide molecule should theoretically exhibit a diketo form. However, X-ray analysis revealed that the C8–O2 distance of 1.285(5) Å is longer than that of the C7–O1 (1.251(5) Å), and the C15–O3 distance of 1.313(5) Å is longer than that of C16–O4 (1.247(5) Å), suggesting that BPTH in compound 1 exists not in the diketo form. O2 and O3 are the hydroxy O atoms, whereas O1 and O4 are the keto O atoms. Obviously, the isomerization for the biphthalhydrazide molecule has occurred (also see Scheme 1), and BPTH exists in the ketohydroxy form. Due to the isomerization, the C8–N2 distance of 1.310(5) Å is shorter than that of the C7–N1 (1.354(5) Å), and the C16–N4 of 1.342(5) Å distance is shorter than that of the C15–N3 (1.302(5) Å). When the biphthalhydrazide molecule coordinates to the Cd2+ ions, two hydroxyls will deprotonate to balance the charge of the Cd2+ ions. So in the compound, BPTH shows −2 oxidation states.

Single-crystal X-ray analysis revealed that compound 1 is a BPTH-bridged 1-D chained Cd(II) coordination polymer with ancillary phen molecules. Compound 1 crystallizes in space group P−1, and the asymmetric unit is found to be composed of one Cd(II) ion (Cd1), one BPTH molecule, one phen molecule as well as 3.75 lattice water molecule. As shown in Fig. 1a, the crystallographically independent Cd1 center with an octahedral geometry is coordinated by two phen N atoms (N5, N6), one hydroxylimino group (N2, O2) and two hydroxylimino O atoms (O3a, O3b). The Cd1–N2hydroxylimino distance of 2.332(4) Å is comparable with those of the Cd–Nphen (Cd–N5 = 2.345(4) Å, Cd–N6 = 2.318(4) Å). The Cd1–O3a distance of 2.283(3) Å and the Cd1–O3b distance of 2.289(3) Å are comparable with each other, but slightly shorter than that of the Cd1–O2 (2.366(3) Å). BPTH adopts a μ3-bridging mode (see Scheme 1): one acylhydrazine ring uses the hydroxylimino O atom to bind to two Cd2+ centers, whereas the other acylhydrazine ring uses the hydroxylimino group to chelate to one Cd2+ center. Two acylamino groups are uncoordinated. Bridged by μ3-mode BPTH molecules, compound 1 shows a 1-D double-chain structure based on the dinuclear Cd2O2 clusters. First of all, two symmetric related BPTH molecules with the hydroxylimino O atoms link alternate two Cd(II) centers to form a dinuclear Cd2O2 cluster. The Cd2O2 cluster is planar with Cd···Cd contact of 3.7022(8) Å. The adjacent Cd2O2 clusters are further linked together via the covalent-bond interactions between the hydroxylimino groups and the Cd centers, forming finally the 1-D double-chain structure of compound 1. If the BPTH molecule is regarded as a rod, compound 1 shows a staircase chain structure (see Fig. 1b). Different from the situation found in the reported compounds [10, 11], the Cd1c···Cd1a contact of 11.546 Å in compound 1 is by far longer than that of the Cd1···Cd1c.

Figure 2 illustrates the 2-D hydrogen-bonded network for compound 1. The adjacent uncoordinated acylamino groups head-to-head form the hydrogen-bonded dimer via intermolecular N–H···O interactions. The hydrogen-bonded parameters are N1···O4e = 2.774 Å, ∠N1–H1a···O4e = 177.36 (e: x, y − 1, z − 1) and N4···O1d = 2.820 Å, ∠N4–H4a···O1d = 169.07 (d: x, y + 1, z + 1), respectively (see Table 3). Through the hydrogen-bonded interactions, the 1-D staircase chains self-assemble into a 2-D supramolecular layer. Note that the hydrogen-bonded chain constructed up from the BPTH molecules shows a linear shape, extending along the a-axial direction.

Figure 3 shows the IR spectrum of compound 1. The IR spectrum of bpha is also given for comparison. In the previous report, we ever drew a conclusion that the ν(COO) peaks for the polycarboxylic acids are generally either larger than 1,680 cm−1 or smaller than 1,610 cm−1, whereas the ν(CONH) peaks for the acylhydrazidate-coordinated compounds generally appear in the range of 1,630–1,675 cm−1 [8]. Based on this, the strong peak at 1,651 cm−1 for compound 1 indicates that the acylation reaction between bpha and N2H4·H2O has occurred. By the way, the ν(COO) peak for bpha is 1,785 cm−1.

Figure 4 is the experimental and the simulated powder XRD patterns for compound 1. The experimental XRD pattern is in accord with the simulated one generated on the basis of structural data, confirming that the as-synthesized products is pure phase. The differences in the intensity may be due to the preferred orientation of the crystals.

The thermal stability of compound 1 was investigated, and the temperature (°C) versus weight-loss (%) curve is shown in Fig. 5. Obviously, compound 1 underwent three-steps of weight losses. Once heated, compound 1 began to lose the weight. In the temperature range of 30–120 °C, compound 1 lost 10.50% weight, corresponding the loss of the lattice water molecules in the compound (Calcd. 9.93%). In the temperature range of 380–540 °C, compound 1 underwent two-steps of continuous weight losses, which are ascribed to the losses of organic phen and BPTH molecules. The final rescue was proved to be CdO. The calculated result (18.87%) is basically comparable with the observed one (19.00%). In fact, compound 1 possesses the better thermal stability, because the temperature for the collapse of the host framework is 380 °C.

Most of the reported acylhydrazidate-coordinated compounds exhibit the excellent photoluminescence properties. For examples, compound [Cu(PTH)] exhibits a red-light emission (636 nm) [5], compound [H(DCPTH)] exhibits a blue-light emission (460 nm) [8], compound [Pb(MPDH)2] exhibits a yellow-light emission (600 nm) [7], and compound [Cd(MPDH)2] exhibits a green-light emission (540 nm) [4]. However, the photoluminescence analysis indicates that the title compound 1 does not emit the light. The reason needs a further study.

Conclusion

In a word, we reported the crystal structure of a new BPTH-bridged 1-D chained Cd2+ coordination polymer [Cd(BPTH)(phen)]·3.75H2O 1. The BPTH derived from the hydrothermal in situ acylation reaction of bpha with N2H4·H2O.

The hydrogen-bonded parameters are N1⋅⋅⋅O4e = 2.774 Å, ∠N1-H1a⋅⋅⋅O4e = 177.36 (e: x, y - 1, z - 1) and N4⋅⋅⋅O1d = 2.820 Å, ∠N4-H4a⋅⋅⋅O1d = 169.07 (d: x, y + 1, z + 1), respectively (see Table 3). Through the hydrogen-bonded interactions, the 1-D staircase chains self-assemble into a 2-D supramolecular layer. Note that the hydrogen-bonded chain constructed up from the BPTH molecules shows a linear shape, extending along the a-axial direction.Figure 3 shows the IR spectrum of compound 1. The IR spectrum of bpha is also given for comparison. In the previous report, we ever drew a conclusion that the ν(COO) peaks for the polycarboxylic acids are generally either larger than 1,680 cm-1 or smaller than 1,610 cm-1, whereas the ν(CONH) peaks for the acylhydrazidate-coordinated compounds generally appear in the range of 1,630-1,675 cm-1 [8]. Based on this, the strong peak at 1,651 cm-1 for compound 1 indicates that the acylation reaction between bpha and N2H4⋅H2O has occurred. By the way, the ν(COO) peak for bpha is 1,785 cm-1.Figure 4 is the experimental and the simulated powder XRD patterns for compound 1. The experimental XRD pattern is in accord with the simulated one generated on the basis of structural data, confirming that the as-synthesized products is pure phase. The differences in the intensity may be due to the preferred orientation of the crystals.The thermal stability of compound 1 was investigated, and the temperature (°C) versus weight-loss (%) curve is shown in Fig. 5. Obviously, compound 1 underwent three-steps of weight losses. Once heated, compound 1 began to lose the weight. In the temperature range of 30-120 °C, compound 1 lost 10.50% weight, corresponding the loss of the lattice water molecules in the compound (Calcd. 9.93%). In the temperature range of 380-540 °C, compound 1 underwent two-steps of continuous weight losses, which are ascribed to the losses of organic phen and BPTH molecules. The final rescue was proved to be CdO. The calculated result (18.87%) is basically comparable with the observed one (19.00%). In fact, compound 1 possesses the better thermal stability, because the temperature for the collapse of the host framework is 380 °C.Most of the reported acylhydrazidate-coordinated compounds exhibit the excellent photoluminescence properties. For examples, compound [Cu(PTH)] exhibits a red-light emission (636 nm) [5], compound [H(DCPTH)] exhibits a blue-light emission (460 nm) [8], compound [Pb(MPDH)2] exhibits a yellow-light emission (600 nm) [7], and compound [Cd(MPDH)2] exhibits a green-light emission (540 nm) [4]. However, the photoluminescence analysis indicates that the title compound 1 does not emit the light. The reason needs a further study.ConclusionIn a word, we reported the crystal structure of a new BPTH-bridged 1-D chained Cd2+ coordination polymer [Cd(BPTH)(phen)]⋅3.75H2O 1. The BPTH derived from the hydrothermal in situ acylation reaction of bpha with N2H4⋅H2O.AcknowledgmentsThis research was supported by the basic research foundation of Jilin University (No. 200903133) and a branch of cooperation project (No. 3R111N651412).References1.ChenXMTongMLAcc. elements.content: Based on the hydrothermal in situ acylation reaction of 4,4′-biphthalic acid (bpha) with N2H4·H2O, a new acylhydrazidate-bridged 1-D chained Cd2+ coordination polymer [Cd(BPTH)(phen)]·3.75H2O (BPTH = 4,4′-biphthalhydrazidate, phen = phenanthroline) was synthesized, and characterized by elemental analysis, infrared spectroscopy, powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), thermogravimetric analysis and single-crystal XRD. With ancillary phen molecules, the BPTH molecules link the Cd2+ centers into a 1-D staircase chain structure of compound 1 based on the Cd2O2 clusters.
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Based on the hydrothermal in situ acylation reaction of 4,4'-biphthalic acid (bpha) with N2H4⋅H2O, a new acylhydrazidate-bridged 1-D chained Cd2+ coordination polymer [Cd(BPTH)(phen)]⋅3.75H2O (BPTH = 4,4'-biphthalhydrazidate, phen = phenanthroline) was synthesized, and characterized by elemental analysis, infrared spectroscopy, powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), thermogravimetric analysis and single-crystal XRD. With ancillary phen molecules, the BPTH molecules link the Cd2+ centers into a 1-D staircase chain structure of compound 1 based on the Cd2O2 clusters.

Graphical Abstract

Based on the hydrothermal in situ acylation reaction of 4,4'-biphthalic acid (bpha) with N2H4⋅H2O, a new acylhydrazidate-bridged 1-D chained Cd2+ coordination polymer [Cd(BPTH)(phen)]⋅3.75H2O (BPTH = 4,4'-biphthalhydrazidate, phen = phenanthroline) was synthesized. elements.content: The ligand in situ synthesis provides a new approach towards the construction of the novel coordination polymer materials with interesting structures and useful properties [1–3]. At recent, one of the investigations for our group is focused on the structural characterization of the acylhydrazidate-bridged coordination polymers. Herein the acylhydrazidate ligands originated from the hydrothermal in situ acylation reactions between organic polycarboxylic acids and N2H4·H2O. So far, the employed polycarboxylic acids in our lab include phthalic acid, pyridine-2,3-dicarboxylic acid, pyridine-3,4-dicarboxylic acid, 6-methylpyridine-2,3-dicarboxylic acid, 5-ethylpyridine-2,3-dicarboxylic acid, benzene-1,2,4-tricarboxylic acid, 4,5-dichlorophthalic acid and 4,4′-oxydiphthalic acid. The obtained typical acylhydrazidate-bridged coordination polymers include the 0-D [Pb2(ODPTH)2(phen)2(H2O)2] [4], 1-D [Pb(2,3-PDH)2] [5], [Mn(MPDH)2] [6], [Pb2(EPDH)4(H2O)] [7], [Pb2(DCPTH)4(phen)2] [8], 2-D [Cu(PTH)] [5], [Pb4(OH)2(H2O)3(CPTH)3]·2H2O [9] as well as the 3-D [Pb(3,4-PDH)2] [5] (ODPTH = 4,4′-oxydiphthalhydrazidate; 2,3-PDH = pyridine-2,3-dicarboxylhydrazidate; MPDH = 6-methylpyridine-2,3-dicarboxylhydrazidate; EPDH = 5-ethylpyridine-2,3-dicarboxylhydrazidate; DCPTH = dicholophthalhydrazidate; 3,4-PDH = pyridine-3,4-dicarboxyhydrazidate; PTH = phthalhydrazidate; CPTH = 4-carboxylphthalhydrazidate; phen = phenanthroline). In these compounds, the metal ions and the O atoms form the various aggregations. Moreover, most of them show the interesting photoluminescence properties due to the existence of multi-types of charge transfer paths in the compounds. In this article, 4,4′-biphthalic acid (bpha) was selected as the acid precursor, and a new 4,4′-biphthalhydrazidate-bridged 1-D chained coordination polymer [Cd(BPTH)(phen)] (BPTH = 4,4′-biphthalhydrazidate) 1 was luckily obtained.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The ligand in situ synthesis provides a new approach towards the construction of the novel coordination polymer materials with interesting structures and useful properties [1-3]. At recent, one of the investigations for our group is focused on the structural characterization of the acylhydrazidate-bridged coordination polymers. Herein the acylhydrazidate ligands originated from the hydrothermal in situ acylation reactions between organic polycarboxylic acids and N2H4⋅H2O. So far, the employed polycarboxylic acids in our lab include phthalic acid, pyridine-2,3-dicarboxylic acid, pyridine-3,4-dicarboxylic acid, 6-methylpyridine-2,3-dicarboxylic acid, 5-ethylpyridine-2,3-dicarboxylic acid, benzene-1,2,4-tricarboxylic acid, 4,5-dichlorophthalic acid and 4,4'-oxydiphthalic acid. The obtained typical acylhydrazidate-bridged coordination polymers include the 0-D [Pb2(ODPTH)2(phen)2(H2O)2] [4], 1-D [Pb(2,3-PDH)2] [5], [Mn(MPDH)2] [6], [Pb2(EPDH)4(H2O)] [7], [Pb2(DCPTH)4(phen)2] [8], 2-D [Cu(PTH)] [5], [Pb4(OH)2(H2O)3(CPTH)3]⋅2H2O [9] as well as the 3-D [Pb(3,4-PDH)2] [5] (ODPTH = 4,4'-oxydiphthalhydrazidate; 2,3-PDH = pyridine-2,3-dicarboxylhydrazidate; MPDH = 6-methylpyridine-2,3-dicarboxylhydrazidate; EPDH = 5-ethylpyridine-2,3-dicarboxylhydrazidate; DCPTH = dicholophthalhydrazidate; 3,4-PDH = pyridine-3,4-dicarboxyhydrazidate; PTH = phthalhydrazidate; CPTH = 4-carboxylphthalhydrazidate; phen = phenanthroline). In these compounds, the metal ions and the O atoms form the various aggregations. Moreover, most of them show the interesting photoluminescence properties due to the existence of multi-types of charge transfer paths in the compounds. In this article, 4,4'-biphthalic acid (bpha) was selected as the acid precursor, and a new 4,4'-biphthalhydrazidate-bridged 1-D chained coordination polymer [Cd(BPTH)(phen)] (BPTH = 4,4'-biphthalhydrazidate) 1 was luckily obtained.

elements.content: All chemicals are of reagent grade quality, obtained from commercial sources without further purification. Elemental analysis (C, H and N) was performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400LS II elemental analyzer. Infrared (IR) spectrum was recorded on a Perkin Elmer Spectrum 1 spectrophotometer in 4,000–400 cm−1 region using a powdered sample on a KBr plate. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were collected on a Rigaku/max-2550 diffractometer with Cu–Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). Thermogravimetric (TG) behavior was investigated on a Perkin-Elmer TGA-7 instrument with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 in air.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

All chemicals are of reagent grade quality, obtained from commercial sources without further purification. Elemental analysis (C, H and N) was performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400LS II elemental analyzer. Infrared (IR) spectrum was recorded on a Perkin Elmer Spectrum 1 spectrophotometer in 4,000-400 cm-1 region using a powdered sample on a KBr plate. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were collected on a Rigaku/max-2550 diffractometer with Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). Thermogravimetric (TG) behavior was investigated on a Perkin-Elmer TGA-7 instrument with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 in air.

elements.content: To a 15 mL aqueous solution, bpha (147 mg, 0.5 mmol) and N2H4·H2O (0.1 mL) were added, and the mixture was stirred for 30 min. Cd(CH3COO)2·3H2O (133 mg, 0.5 mmol) and phen·H2O (99 mg, 0.5 mmol) were further added, and the mixture continued to be stirred for 3 h. Then the resulting solution (pH 5 adjusted by dilute CH3COOH) was sealed in a 30-mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessels and heated in an oven at 170 °C for 4 days. Upon cooling automatically to the room temperature, yellow block crystals of 1 were obtained by filtration, washed with distilled water and dried in air at the ambient temperature. Yield: ca. 20% based on Cd(II). Anal. Calcd. C28H23.5N6O7.75Cd 1: C 49.43, H 3.48, N 12.35%. Found: C 48.14, H 3.99, N 12.10%. IR (cm−1): 1651 s, 1558 s, 1490 s, 1440 m, 1380 m, 1342 m, 1265 w, 1207 m, 1070 m, 845 s, 793 s, 722 s, 678 w.

[Cd(BPTH)(phen)]⋅3.75H2O 1

To a 15 mL aqueous solution, bpha (147 mg, 0.5 mmol) and N2H4⋅H2O (0.1 mL) were added, and the mixture was stirred for 30 min. Cd(CH3COO)2⋅3H2O (133 mg, 0.5 mmol) and phen⋅H2O (99 mg, 0.5 mmol) were further added, and the mixture continued to be stirred for 3 h. Then the resulting solution (pH 5 adjusted by dilute CH3COOH) was sealed in a 30-mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessels and heated in an oven at 170 °C for 4 days. Upon cooling automatically to the room temperature, yellow block crystals of 1 were obtained by filtration, washed with distilled water and dried in air at the ambient temperature. Yield: ca. 20% based on Cd(II). Anal. Calcd. C28H23.5N6O7.75Cd 1: C 49.43, H 3.48, N 12.35%. Found: C 48.14, H 3.99, N 12.10%. IR (cm-1): 1651 s, 1558 s, 1490 s, 1440 m, 1380 m, 1342 m, 1265 w, 1207 m, 1070 m, 845 s, 793 s, 722 s, 678 w.

elements.content: Data were collected with Mo–Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) on a Siemens SMART CCD diffractometer. With SHELXTL program, compound 1 was solved using direct methods, and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques. The non-hydrogen atoms were assigned anisotropic displacement parameters in the refinement, and the hydrogen atoms were treated using a riding model. The structure was then refined on F2 using SHELXL-97. CCDC number is 833993 for 1. The crystallographic data are summarized in Table 1. The selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table 2.

In the synthesis of compound 1, the aim that bpha and N2H4·H2O were first mixed and stirred for 30 min is to induce the occurrence of the acylation reaction, avoiding producing the carboxylate-bridged coordination polymer. Scheme 1 gives the forming process of the BPTH molecule. One molar bpha interacts with two molar N2H4·H2O, losing six molar water molecules to produce the acylhydrazide molecule.

Results and Discussion

In the synthesis of compound 1, the aim that bpha and N2H4⋅H2O were first mixed and stirred for 30 min is to induce the occurrence of the acylation reaction, avoiding producing the carboxylate-bridged coordination polymer. Scheme 1 gives the forming process of the BPTH molecule. One molar bpha interacts with two molar N2H4⋅H2O, losing six molar water molecules to produce the acylhydrazide molecule.

elements.content: Based on the acylation reaction mechanism (see Scheme 1), the biphthalhydrazide molecule should theoretically exhibit a diketo form. However, X-ray analysis revealed that the C8–O2 distance of 1.285(5) Å is longer than that of the C7–O1 (1.251(5) Å), and the C15–O3 distance of 1.313(5) Å is longer than that of C16–O4 (1.247(5) Å), suggesting that BPTH in compound 1 exists not in the diketo form. O2 and O3 are the hydroxy O atoms, whereas O1 and O4 are the keto O atoms. Obviously, the isomerization for the biphthalhydrazide molecule has occurred (also see Scheme 1), and BPTH exists in the ketohydroxy form. Due to the isomerization, the C8–N2 distance of 1.310(5) Å is shorter than that of the C7–N1 (1.354(5) Å), and the C16–N4 of 1.342(5) Å distance is shorter than that of the C15–N3 (1.302(5) Å). When the biphthalhydrazide molecule coordinates to the Cd2+ ions, two hydroxyls will deprotonate to balance the charge of the Cd2+ ions. So in the compound, BPTH shows −2 oxidation states.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray analysis revealed that compound 1 is a BPTH-bridged 1-D chained Cd(II) coordination polymer with ancillary phen molecules. Compound 1 crystallizes in space group P−1, and the asymmetric unit is found to be composed of one Cd(II) ion (Cd1), one BPTH molecule, one phen molecule as well as 3.75 lattice water molecule. As shown in Fig. 1a, the crystallographically independent Cd1 center with an octahedral geometry is coordinated by two phen N atoms (N5, N6), one hydroxylimino group (N2, O2) and two hydroxylimino O atoms (O3a, O3b). The Cd1–N2hydroxylimino distance of 2.332(4) Å is comparable with those of the Cd–Nphen (Cd–N5 = 2.345(4) Å, Cd–N6 = 2.318(4) Å). The Cd1–O3a distance of 2.283(3) Å and the Cd1–O3b distance of 2.289(3) Å are comparable with each other, but slightly shorter than that of the Cd1–O2 (2.366(3) Å). BPTH adopts a μ3-bridging mode (see Scheme 1): one acylhydrazine ring uses the hydroxylimino O atom to bind to two Cd2+ centers, whereas the other acylhydrazine ring uses the hydroxylimino group to chelate to one Cd2+ center. Two acylamino groups are uncoordinated. Bridged by μ3-mode BPTH molecules, compound 1 shows a 1-D double-chain structure based on the dinuclear Cd2O2 clusters. First of all, two symmetric related BPTH molecules with the hydroxylimino O atoms link alternate two Cd(II) centers to form a dinuclear Cd2O2 cluster. The Cd2O2 cluster is planar with Cd···Cd contact of 3.7022(8) Å. The adjacent Cd2O2 clusters are further linked together via the covalent-bond interactions between the hydroxylimino groups and the Cd centers, forming finally the 1-D double-chain structure of compound 1. If the BPTH molecule is regarded as a rod, compound 1 shows a staircase chain structure (see Fig. 1b). Different from the situation found in the reported compounds [10, 11], the Cd1c···Cd1a contact of 11.546 Å in compound 1 is by far longer than that of the Cd1···Cd1c.

elements.content: Figure 2 illustrates the 2-D hydrogen-bonded network for compound 1. The adjacent uncoordinated acylamino groups head-to-head form the hydrogen-bonded dimer via intermolecular N–H···O interactions. The hydrogen-bonded parameters are N1···O4e = 2.774 Å, ∠N1–H1a···O4e = 177.36 (e: x, y − 1, z − 1) and N4···O1d = 2.820 Å, ∠N4–H4a···O1d = 169.07 (d: x, y + 1, z + 1), respectively (see Table 3). Through the hydrogen-bonded interactions, the 1-D staircase chains self-assemble into a 2-D supramolecular layer. Note that the hydrogen-bonded chain constructed up from the BPTH molecules shows a linear shape, extending along the a-axial direction.

Figure 3 shows the IR spectrum of compound 1. The IR spectrum of bpha is also given for comparison. In the previous report, we ever drew a conclusion that the ν(COO) peaks for the polycarboxylic acids are generally either larger than 1,680 cm−1 or smaller than 1,610 cm−1, whereas the ν(CONH) peaks for the acylhydrazidate-coordinated compounds generally appear in the range of 1,630–1,675 cm−1 [8]. Based on this, the strong peak at 1,651 cm−1 for compound 1 indicates that the acylation reaction between bpha and N2H4·H2O has occurred. By the way, the ν(COO) peak for bpha is 1,785 cm−1.

elements.content: The thermal stability of compound 1 was investigated, and the temperature (°C) versus weight-loss (%) curve is shown in Fig. 5. Obviously, compound 1 underwent three-steps of weight losses. Once heated, compound 1 began to lose the weight. In the temperature range of 30–120 °C, compound 1 lost 10.50% weight, corresponding the loss of the lattice water molecules in the compound (Calcd. 9.93%). In the temperature range of 380–540 °C, compound 1 underwent two-steps of continuous weight losses, which are ascribed to the losses of organic phen and BPTH molecules. The final rescue was proved to be CdO. The calculated result (18.87%) is basically comparable with the observed one (19.00%). In fact, compound 1 possesses the better thermal stability, because the temperature for the collapse of the host framework is 380 °C.

elements.content: Most of the reported acylhydrazidate-coordinated compounds exhibit the excellent photoluminescence properties. For examples, compound [Cu(PTH)] exhibits a red-light emission (636 nm) [5], compound [H(DCPTH)] exhibits a blue-light emission (460 nm) [8], compound [Pb(MPDH)2] exhibits a yellow-light emission (600 nm) [7], and compound [Cd(MPDH)2] exhibits a green-light emission (540 nm) [4]. However, the photoluminescence analysis indicates that the title compound 1 does not emit the light. The reason needs a further study.

elements.content: In a word, we reported the crystal structure of a new BPTH-bridged 1-D chained Cd2+ coordination polymer [Cd(BPTH)(phen)]·3.75H2O 1. The BPTH derived from the hydrothermal in situ acylation reaction of bpha with N2H4·H2O.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In a word, we reported the crystal structure of a new BPTH-bridged 1-D chained Cd2+ coordination polymer [Cd(BPTH)(phen)]⋅3.75H2O 1. The BPTH derived from the hydrothermal in situ acylation reaction of bpha with N2H4⋅H2O.

cln_elements.content: To a 15 mL aqueous solution, bpha (147 mg, 0.5 mmol) and N2H4·H2O (0.1 mL) were added, and the mixture was stirred for 30 min. Cd(CH3COO)2·3H2O (133 mg, 0.5 mmol) and phen·H2O (99 mg, 0.5 mmol) were further added, and the mixture continued to be stirred for 3 h. Then the resulting solution (pH 5 adjusted by dilute CH3COOH) was sealed in a 30-mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessels and heated in an oven at 170 °C for 4 days. Upon cooling automatically to the room temperature, yellow block crystals of 1 were obtained by filtration, washed with distilled water and dried in air at the ambient temperature. Yield: ca. 20% based on Cd(II). Anal. Calcd. C28H23.5N6O7.75Cd 1: C 49.43, H 3.48, N 12.35%. Found: C 48.14, H 3.99, N 12.10%. IR (cm−1): 1651 s, 1558 s, 1490 s, 1440 m, 1380 m, 1342 m, 1265 w, 1207 m, 1070 m, 845 s, 793 s, 722 s, 678 w.
cln_elements.clean_text:
[Cd(BPTH)(phen)]⋅3.75H2O 1

To a 15 mL aqueous solution, bpha (147 mg, 0.5 mmol) and N2H4⋅H2O (0.1 mL) were added, and the mixture was stirred for 30 min. Cd(CH3COO)2⋅3H2O (133 mg, 0.5 mmol) and phen⋅H2O (99 mg, 0.5 mmol) were further added, and the mixture continued to be stirred for 3 h. Then the resulting solution (pH 5 adjusted by dilute CH3COOH) was sealed in a 30-mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessels and heated in an oven at 170 °C for 4 days. Upon cooling automatically to the room temperature, yellow block crystals of 1 were obtained by filtration, washed with distilled water and dried in air at the ambient temperature. Yield: ca. 20% based on Cd(II). Anal. Calcd. C28H23.5N6O7.75Cd 1: C 49.43, H 3.48, N 12.35%. Found: C 48.14, H 3.99, N 12.10%. IR (cm-1): 1651 s, 1558 s, 1490 s, 1440 m, 1380 m, 1342 m, 1265 w, 1207 m, 1070 m, 845 s, 793 s, 722 s, 678 w.

cln_elements.content:
The thermal stability of compound 1 was investigated, and the temperature (°C) versus weight-loss (%) curve is shown in Fig. 5. Obviously, compound 1 underwent three-steps of weight losses. Once heated, compound 1 began to lose the weight. In the temperature range of 30–120 °C, compound 1 lost 10.50% weight, corresponding the loss of the lattice water molecules in the compound (Calcd. 9.93%). In the temperature range of 380–540 °C, compound 1 underwent two-steps of continuous weight losses, which are ascribed to the losses of organic phen and BPTH molecules. The final rescue was proved to be CdO. The calculated result (18.87%) is basically comparable with the observed one (19.00%). In fact, compound 1 possesses the better thermal stability, because the temperature for the collapse of the host framework is 380 °C.

Most of the reported acylhydrazidate-coordinated compounds exhibit the excellent photoluminescence properties. For examples, compound [Cu(PTH)] exhibits a red-light emission (636 nm) [5], compound [H(DCPTH)] exhibits a blue-light emission (460 nm) [8], compound [Pb(MPDH)2] exhibits a yellow-light emission (600 nm) [7], and compound [Cd(MPDH)2] exhibits a green-light emission (540 nm) [4]. However, the photoluminescence analysis indicates that the title compound 1 does not emit the light. The reason needs a further study.

The final rescue was proved to be CdO. The calculated result (18.87%) is basically comparable with the observed one (19.00%). In fact, compound 1 possesses the better thermal stability, because the temperature for the collapse of the host framework is 380 °C.

Most of the reported acylhydrazidate-coordinated compounds exhibit the excellent photoluminescence properties. For examples, compound [Cu(PTH)] exhibits a red-light emission (636 nm) [5], compound [H(DCPTH)] exhibits a blue-light emission (460 nm) [8], compound [Pb(MPDH)2] exhibits a yellow-light emission (600 nm) [7], and compound [Cd(MPDH)2] exhibits a green-light emission (540 nm) [4]. However, the photoluminescence analysis indicates that the title compound 1 does not emit the light. The reason needs a further study.
